channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: An Indian Film Embraces a Taj Majal Conspiracy Theory
item.description: The internet and a new film have breathed life into old conspiracy theories about one of the world’s most famous landmarks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Saumya Khandelwal

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Uber Found Liable in Rape by Driver, Setting Stage for Thousands of Cases
item.description: In a federal bellwether case, the jury ordered the ride-hailing giant to pay $8.5 million to Jaylynn Dean, who said one of its drivers assaulted her in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jaylynn Dean at a hotel in Phoenix, where a federal jury awarded her damages on Thursday.

item.title: Bitcoin Drops to Lowest Price Since Trump Was Elected as Crypto Faces Slump
item.description: The price of Bitcoin is now lower than when President Trump was elected in 2024, raising concerns of a new “crypto winter" in the industry.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: TrumpRx Is Set to Go Live on Thursday
item.description: The government website is meant to connect Americans with drug companies to buy prescriptions directly with their own money. It is not clear how many patients will save money.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: President Trump announced an effort to lower drug prices last year.

item.title: Brad Karp’s Fall Shows Growing Fallout From Epstein Files
item.description: Brad Karp’s resignation as chairman of the law firm Paul Weiss underscores a further reflection in the corporate world over the latest revelations.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newly published files showed that Brad Karp had visited Jeffrey Epstein’s Manhattan mansion and sought a job for his son on a Woody Allen movie, among other revelations.

item.title: As Silver Prices Soar, Pandora Switches to Platinum
item.description: Pandora, known for its charm bracelets, is trying to reduce its exposure to the volatility in silver prices, the latest setback for a company also facing wary consumers and steep tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Rising silver prices have challenged Pandora’s “affordable luxury” model, driving up costs for its core material.

item.title: William Shatner Pitches Raisin Bran in Super Bowl Commercial
item.description: WK Kellogg is promoting Raisin Bran with William Shatner during the big game as cereal sales decline. It’s also tapping the latest health and wellness trend.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell

item.title: He Was Laid Off at The Washington Post After Working There 60 Years
item.description: Martin Weil, one of hundreds being let go at The Post, has worked on local news there since 1965, witnessing the paper’s rise and now retrenchment.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The thrill of a byline in The Washington Post “never went away,” said Martin Weil, at his home in the city.

item.title: Files Reveal Epstein’s Money Mingled with Silicon Valley’s Tech Start-Ups
item.description: The disgraced financier regularly courted tech industry figures not just for their prestige but also for access to promising companies.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Erin Griffith and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:credit: Department of Justice, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Last week’s disclosures of Jeffrey Epstein’s communications offer insight into how he made his money as an investor after his 2008 conviction.

item.title: Brad Karp Resigns as Paul Weiss Chairman Amid Epstein Fallout
item.description: The decision followed the release of a series of embarrassing emails between Mr. Karp and Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein, Michael S. Schmidt and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Recent reporting has created a distraction and has placed a focus on me that is not in the best interests of the firm,” Brad Karp said in a statement from Paul Weiss.

item.title: Senators Accuse Equifax of ‘Price-Gouging’ Medicaid Programs
item.description: The company’s data will be essential for many states to comply with new work requirements for the health insurance program that take effect next year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff, Margot Sanger-Katz and Asmaa Elkeurti
item.media:description: Many states rely on an Equifax product to verify Medicaid applicants’ wages and work hours.

item.title: The Washington Post Eliminates Its Sports Department
item.description: The Post is laying off or reassigning all the reporters and editors in its sports section, days before the Super Bowl and the Winter Olympics in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washington Post leadership announced major layoffs within the newsroom.

item.title: Google Plans to Double Spending Amid A.I. Race
item.description: Profits jumped 30 percent to $34.5 billion last quarter, and the tech giant is increasing its capital spending this year to as much as $185 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Google ad in Times Square.

item.title: Bessent Says Fed Lacks Accountability and Has Lost Public Trust
item.description: In a House committee hearing, the Treasury secretary declined to say if the president has the power to fire a member of the central bank’s board.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent testified on Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee.

item.title: F.T.C. Settles With Express Scripts Over High Insulin Prices
item.description: The Trump administration announced that the company, a pharmacy benefit manager, had agreed to make significant changes to its practices.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Reed Abelson
item.media:credit: Sarah Holm/The Virginian-Pilot, via Associated Press
item.media:description: High insulin prices generated public outcry for years, though changes in the past few years have reduced patients’ costs to no more than $35 a month in most cases.

item.title: Nike, Accused of Bias Against White Workers, Is Under Federal Investigation
item.description: It appeared to be the first time the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has targeted diversity policies at a large company.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Kim Bhasin
item.media:description: Nike has sponsorship partnerships with world-famous athletes including LeBron James and Caitlin Clark.

item.title: France’s Raid on X Escalates Trans-Atlantic Showdown Over Social Media
item.description: The French investigation into Elon Musk’s X illustrated a fundamental divide between European and American leaders about how to regulate social media — or whether to restrict it at all.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: A poster in London featuring an image of Elon Musk, calling for X users to delete their accounts.

item.title: Are You ‘Biohacking’ to Perform Better at Work? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: Please tell us what changes you’ve made to your health and wellness practices to improve your brain function and job performance. We may include your experiences in an article.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: Some people track their sleep quality or heart rate variability through an Apple Watch and try to improve them.

item.title: State Fiscal Chiefs Protest Federal Immigration Chaos
item.description: Sixteen elected treasury officials, all Democrats, wrote to President Trump to say ICE crackdowns are bad for business and tax revenues: “People must feel safe to go to work.”
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Yasmin Yassin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Minneapolis last week. The presence of ICE in the city has hurt economic activity.

item.title: Washington Post Cuts More Than 300 Jobs
item.description: The layoffs cut into The Post’s local, international and sports coverage, and reduced its entire work force by about 30 percent.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Erik Wemple
item.media:description: Matt Murray, executive editor of The Washington Post, told employees that the revamped paper would focus more on national news and politics, and business and health, and less on other areas.

item.title: Why A.I. Fears Are Battering Stocks, Again
item.description: New tools by artificial intelligence companies like Anthropic have reignited worries that businesses will pare down their subscriptions to software services.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Grady McGregor
item.media:credit: Marissa Leshnov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investors are fleeing software stocks as A.I. companies like Anthropic introduce more-sophisticated business tools.

item.title: Novo Nordisk Warns of First Sales Drop Since Start of Ozempic
item.description: The once high-flying Danish drugmaker has struggled to fend off rivals in the weight-loss industry, especially Eli Lilly, which gave a much rosier outlook to investors.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shares of Novo Nordisk, once Europe’s most valuable public company, have fallen significantly from their peak in 2024.

item.title: Bedrock, an A.I. Start-Up for Construction, Raises $270 Million
item.description: The two-year-old company, founded by veterans of the autonomous vehicle business Waymo, is seeking to automate excavators and other building equipment.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: Bedrock Robotics says its products could eventually allow contractors to work on projects as long as 24 hours a day.

item.title: New York Times Added 1.4 Million Digital Subscribers in 2025
item.description: The company reported total revenue of $802.3 million for the fourth quarter of 2025, up 10.4 percent from a year earlier.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times is on track to meet its goal of 15 million total subscribers by the end of next year.

item.title: Bulgarians Adopt the Euro With a Whisper of Melancholy but Few Tears
item.description: In a country roiled by political upheaval recently, retiring the longtime currency, the lev, prompted some concern about inflation but little other angst.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Boryana Dzhambazova
item.media:description: A billboard in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, on New Year’s Day. The changeover to euros was long anticipated but divided public opinion nonetheless.

item.title: NFL Wants to Revise TV Deals Years Before They Expire
item.description: The league is so important to the business of media companies that they are likely to have little choice but to agree to renegotiations.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and John Koblin
item.media:description: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, at a news conference on Monday in San Jose, Calif. Last year, he said of the league: “I always think we’re undervalued.”

item.title: Once the Hottest Bet on Wall St., Private Credit Has Started to Crack
item.description: Concerns about defaults, particularly among software companies, have spooked investors in the private credit firms that lend to them.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell
item.media:description: Blue Owl Capital’s shares have lost more than half their value over the past year.

item.title: For a Long Valentine’s Weekend, 6 Wellness Getaways
item.description: Couples have three days to celebrate togetherness this year, and resorts and hotels are going all out on the feel-good front.
item.dc:creator: Amy Thomas

item.title: Trump Says Housing Prices Should Be Higher, Not Lower
item.description: When President Trump said he wanted to drive housing prices up, not down, he was speaking to a conundrum that has flummoxed policymakers for decades.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: New homes in Daybreak, Utah. In the years since the Covid-19 pandemic, home prices have risen about 50 percent.

item.title: Congress Targets Housing Crisis as Solutions Elude Trump
item.description: Bipartisan Senate and House packages, aimed at rewarding new construction and eliminating red tape, could bring significant changes to federal housing laws.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: A suburban housing development in Seguin, Texas. A housing shortage is the main reason for the affordability problem in the United States.

item.title: A Journalist Who Looks for Clues in Plain Sight
item.description: On The Times’s Visual Investigations team, Christiaan Triebert combines social media sleuthing and traditional reporting to piece together complex stories.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Congress Reins In Drug Middlemen in Effort to Lower Prescription Prices
item.description: The legislation will impose new restrictions on pharmacy benefit managers, giant companies like CVS Caremark, Optum Rx and Express Scripts that oversee prescription drug benefits.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Executives at the largest pharmacy benefit managers testified before a congressional committee in 2023.

item.title: ‘Neoroyalism’ and What It Says About Trump
item.description: Experts are reaching to divine the president’s approach to global policy and economics, with one theory seeing antecedents in centuries-old dynastic rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman gave President Trump a warm and opulent welcome in Saudi Arabia last year.

item.title: Netflix Leader Pushes Warner Deal Before Skeptical Lawmakers
item.description: Senators asked Ted Sarandos about whether the acquisition would raise prices, squeeze talent and degrade the moviegoing experience.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ted Sarandos, left, a co-chief executive of Netflix, and Bruce Campbell, right, chief revenue and strategy officer of Warner Bros. Discovery. Mr. Sarandos told a Senate subcommittee on Tuesday that “we’ll keep growing the American entertainment industry.”

item.title: Stephen Miran Resigns From White House as Fed Term Stretches On
item.description: Mr. Miran had taken a leave of absence from advising the president after adding a role at the Federal Reserve, drawing criticism from Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Tony Romm
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Miran, who is resigning as chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, can continue to serve as a Federal Reserve governor until a replacement is confirmed.

item.title: Grammy Awards Audience Declines by a Million Viewers
item.description: The show on Sunday drew about 14.4 million people. It is the second consecutive year that the awards ceremony attracted a smaller audience.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for The Recording Academy
item.media:description: Bruno Mars performing at the Grammy Awards on Sunday. As recently as 2024, the show had nearly 17 million viewers.

item.title: Meat Processors Take a Hit as Cattle Prices Remain High
item.description: Tyson Foods said its beef business could lose up to $500 million this year as the supply of cattle reaches a 75-year low.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:description: Tyson Foods is among the companies struggling with the cost of beef, as the U.S. cattle supply remains at its lowest level since 1951.

item.title: Virginia Oliver, Maine’s ‘Lobster Lady’ and Folk Hero, Dies at 105
item.description: She fished off the New England coast for more than 80 years, and intended to continue until she died. “It’s not hard work for me,” she said at 101.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:description: Ms. Oliver in 2021, when she was 101. “She represented that no-nonsense Mainer who just got up every day and did what they had to do,” said Barbara Walsh, the author of a children’s book about Mrs. Oliver.

item.title: Walmart Joins Tech Giants With $1 Trillion Market Valuation
item.description: The company’s rapid e-commerce growth and push into automation and artificial intelligence propelled its stock into the trillion-dollar club.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: The Questionable Science Behind the Odd-Looking Football Helmets
item.description: The N.F.L. claims Guardian Caps reduce the risk of concussions. The company that makes them says, “It has nothing to do with concussions.”
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: Jared Wilson, an offensive lineman for the Patriots, wore a Guardian Cap at the A.F.C. Championship game against the Broncos.

item.title: ‘Don Colossus,’ a Golden Statue of President Trump, Waits for Its Home
item.description: A group of cryptocurrency investors backing a memecoin hopes the statue will soon be installed at one of Mr. Trump’s golf courses in Florida.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Trust Reveals Beneficiaries of His Fortune
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein wanted most of his money to go to his girlfriend. Mr. Epstein’s brother and a Harvard math professor were also named beneficiaries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: It’s unclear how much any of the beneficiaries to Jeffrey Epstein’s estate will receive. Its value has dropped significantly since his death, owing to payment of taxes, legal fees and settlements to victims of his sexual abuse.

item.title: Christy Tanner Named C.E.O. of New York Public Radio
item.description: Ms. Tanner was previously an executive at CBS News and serves on the board of Audacy, a major U.S. broadcaster and podcast producer.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:credit: Katie Jones/Variety, via Penske Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Christy Tanner, the next chief executive of New York Public Radio.

item.title: After Years of Increases, PepsiCo Pledges to Cut Prices on Snacks
item.description: The food and beverage giant said consumers were facing “affordability limitations.”
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:description: PepsiCo said it had “begun offering greater affordability on certain packages of iconic brands,” including Doritos and Cheetos.

item.title: Disney Names Josh D’Amaro as Next C.E.O.
item.description: Mr. D’Amaro, 54, has most recently served as chairman of Disney Experiences, a division that includes theme parks, cruise vacations and consumer products.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Josh D’Amaro was named Disney’s next chief executive.

item.title: The Numbers, and Questions, Behind Musk’s Mega-Merger
item.description: The combination of SpaceX and xAI will create a rocket-and-A.I. giant. But investors and experts have concerns about the consequences of the deal.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX is now a rocket-launching giant, a dominant force in satellite internet, a money-burning artificial intelligence business and a popular but divisive social media company.

item.title: Police Search X’s Premises in France as Prosecutors Summon Elon Musk
item.description: The move followed a yearlong investigation into X and escalated a wider standoff between European officials and American tech companies over the regulation of social media.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Elon Musk in Davos, Switzerland, in January.

item.title: Investigation Finds Credit Suisse Had Wider Nazi Ties Than Previously Known
item.description: But a lawyer who has been scrutinizing archives and UBS are in a dispute over access to about 150 documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: “Shining light on Credit Suisse’s past is part of turning the page, a very dark chapter of history,” said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

item.title: Siemens Energy Bets $1 Billion That A.I. Power Demand Will Last
item.description: The German manufacturer announced plans to expand factories in several U.S. states and build a new plant in Mississippi.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:description: A Siemens Energy factory in Berlin in 2017. The company is one of the world’s biggest manufacturers of gas turbines.
